problem: The vertices of the square are located at $A(1,1), B(4,1), C(4,4), D(1,4)$. If the square is rotated 90 degrees counterclockwise about the origin, what is the abscissa of the new position of point $C$?
solution: When rotating a point $(x, y)$ 90 degrees counterclockwise about the origin, the new coordinates become $(-y, x)$. Thus, point $C(4, 4)$ becomes $C'(-4, 4)$. Therefore the answer is $\boxed{-4}$.
